Embryology 1988 1
Gel Retardation Assay
This assay was developed by Fried and Cruthers 9, 6505 (1981)] and
Garner and Revsin 9, 3047 (l98l)] for analyzing protein-DNA interactions
by separating protein-DNA complexes from free DNA by polyacrylamide gel
electrophoresis.
Low crosslinking horizontal polyacrylamide gels are poured and allowed to
polymerize. Protein, at an appropriate concentration, is added to an
incubation buffer containing a labeled DNA fragment as well as competitor DNA.
After a brief incubation at room temperature the samples are rapidly mixed with
sample buffer and immediately loaded on a running gel.
The gel retardation assay is a simple and sensitive method for determining
interactions between protein and DNA. Unlike footprinting techniques that rely
on the loss of a signal to determine prOtein-DNA interactions (negative assay),
the gel retardation assay yields a positive signal; the appearace of a DNA
fragment with an altered mobility. Therefore, effects that are undetectable in
a negative assay are easily visualized by the gel retardation assay. An
unexpected property of the gel assay is its ability to "freeze" equilibria
allowing detection and physical separation of alternative conformational states
of complexes that rapidly equilibrate in solution.
A major disadvantage of the gel retardation assay is that it does not give
a direct readout of the DNA nucleotides that the protein is recognizing. For
this type of information, a higher resolution technique such as 
footprinting or methylation interference is invaluable. Fourtunately, these
application can often be coupled with the retardation assay with considerable
advantage.
Our demonstration will attempt to illustrate the ease and power of the gel
retardation assay as well as some of the common technical pitfalls and
misinterpretations of the results.
1) Pour gel; let it polymerize for 1 hour. (see page 2)
After gel polymerizes remove comb and rinse wells with water.
Protein:DNA binding reaction (20 ul reaction)
2) In an 1.5 ml eppendorf tube add;
a) 17 pl of binding buffer
b) 1 pl of 32P DNA fragment(s) to be tested (~l0`11M) (~2000 cpm)
c) pl of lmg/ml poly dl/dC (competitor DNA)
d) pl of protein of purified protein)
3) Incubate at room temp for 5 minutes. Add of sample buffer.
4) Load onto a running gel and electrophorese for hr at 250 volts in
O.5X TBE.
5) Dry gel under vacuum at for 30 minutes.
6) Dried gels are autoradiographed for several hours to visualize
the DNA bands.
